questions.question: Which museum, located in the capital of a European country, is renowned for housing the Mona Lisa and is one of the largest and most visited museums in the world?
questions.context: Before becoming a museum in 1793, this building was originally a fortress and later a royal palace in France.

questions.question: What is the ancient ruin located in the Andes Mountains, once a 15th-century Inca civilization site, known worldwide for its sophisticated dry-stone construction?
questions.context: Discovered to the outside world by Hiram Bingham in 1911, this site was an estate for the Inca emperor Pachacuti.

questions.question: At which NASA facility, located in the southern United States, were the Apollo missions controlled, making it a key site in space exploration history?
questions.context: This center was the home for Mission Control during the moon landings and is still active in controlling the International Space Station operations.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site in Italy, buried by a volcanic eruption in 79 AD, offers unparalleled insight into Roman life?
questions.context: The nearby Mount Vesuvius eruption preserved this city's buildings, artifacts, and even some of its citizens in volcanic ash.

questions.question: Which historical battle site in Belgium, where Napoleon Bonaparte faced decisive defeat in 1815, marked the end of the Napoleonic Wars?
questions.context: This battle was fought near a town around 15 kilometers south of Brussels and involved various European coalitions.
